title: Suede
text:
{{Short description|Type of leather with a napped finish}}
{{for multi|the English rock band|Suede (band)|other uses}}
[[File:George-Boot Carson (Grenson).jpg|thumb|right|250px|Suede boot]]

'''Suede''' (pronounced {{IPAc-en|s|w|eɪ|d}} {{respell|SWAYD}}) is a type of [[leather]] with a fuzzy, napped finish, commonly used for [[jacket]]s, [[shoe]]s, [[Textile|fabrics]], [[Handbag|purses]], [[furniture]], and other items. The term comes from the French {{lang|fr|gants de Suède}}, which literally means "gloves from [[Sweden]]".<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/suede Suede],  Dictionary.com</ref>

Suede is made from the underside of the animal skin, which is softer and more pliable than the outer skin layer, though not as durable.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://explainry.com/difference-between/leather-suede/|title=Difference Between Leather and Suede - Explainry|newspaper=Explainry|access-date=2017-02-11|language=en-US}}</ref>

==Production==
{{unreferenced section|date=August 2021}}
[[File:Afghaanse jas van bruine suède met langharig bont langs de randen en manchetten en doorgestikt borduursel in crème en roze, haaksluiting voorzijde, objectnr 24389(1).JPG|thumb|right|upright|Suede jacket]]
Suede leather is made from the underside of the skin,<ref>{{Cite book|last=Scrivano|first=Sandy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3ZXZ6f2KNLwC&dq=Suede+leather+is+made+from+the+underside+of+the+skin&pg=PA120|title=Sewing with Leather and Suede: Tips, Techniques and Inspiration|date=2001|publisher=Lark Books|isbn=978-1-57990-273-5|pages=120|language=en}}</ref> primarily from [[domestic sheep|lamb]], although [[goat]], [[calfskin|calf]], and [[deer]] are commonly used. Splits from thick hides of cow and deer are also sueded, but, due to the fiber content, have a shaggy nap. 

==Characteristics==

{{unreferenced section|date=August 2021}}
Because suede does not include the tough exterior skin layer, it is less durable, but softer, than the standard "full-grain" leather. Its softness, thinness, and pliability make it suitable for clothing and delicate uses; suede was originally used for women's [[gloves]], hence its etymology (see above). Suede leather is also popular in [[upholstery]], [[shoe]]s, [[handbag|bags]], and other accessories, and as a [[lining (sewing)|lining]] for other leather products. Due to its textured nature and open pores, suede may become dirty and quickly absorb liquids.

== Sueded fabrics==
Fabric sueding is carried out on a sueding machine with abrasive covered rollers; the machines can suede both sides of fabric, whether woven or knitted.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_textile-manufacturer-knitting-world_1977_1|title=Textile Manufacturer & Knitting World 1977: Iss 1|date=1977|publisher=Textile Manufacturer|others=Internet Archive|pages=19|language=English}}</ref> Creasing and variations in the center selvedge are two major concerns with sueded fabrics.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_textile-technology-digest_1996-06_53|title=Textile Technology Digest 1996-06: Vol 53|date=1996|publisher=Textile Information Center|others=Internet Archive|pages=62|language=English}}</ref> Fabrics that have been sueded or emerized are known as 'sueded fabrics' or 'emerized fabrics.' <ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|title=Definition of SUEDE|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/suede|access-date=2021-08-03|website=www.merriam-webster.com|language=en}}</ref>

=== Sueding ===
Sueding is a [[Chemical finishing of textiles#Mechanical finishes|mechanical finishing process]] that exposes the material to an abrasive surface, creating a small, soft pile. The abrasion mechanism may be equipped with  [[sandpaper]], [[emery paper]] or carbon brushes.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|last=Elsasser|first=Virginia Hencken|url=https://archive.org/details/textiles00virg|title=Textiles : concepts and principles|date=2005|publisher=New York, NY : Fairchild Publications|others=Internet Archive|isbn=978-1-56367-300-9|pages=231}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5Zm1AAAAIAAJ&q=carbon+brushes+sueding|title=A.T.A. Journal|date=2006|publisher=Adsale Publishing Company|pages=24|language=en}}</ref>

==== Sueding action ====
The abrasive material on the machine's rollers cuts and shreds surface fibres, resulting in a soft texture with a short pile.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Joseph|first=Marjory L.|url=https://archive.org/details/josephsintroduct06edjose|title=Joseph's introductory textile science|date=1992|publisher=Fort Worth : Harcourt Brace Jovanovich College Publishers|others=Internet Archive|isbn=978-0-03-050723-6|pages=339}}</ref>

===== Trademarked sueded fabrics =====
[[Alcantara (material)|Alcantara]] and [[Ultrasuede]] are trademarked names for a plush [[microfiber]] with a feel resembling soft suede; this type of material is more durable and resistant to liquids and stains, and can be used in upholstery, accessories, clothing or shoes.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Alcantara: sustainability and versatility|url=https://www.alcantara.com/|access-date=2021-08-03|website=Alcantara}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=The Indian Head Connection - Skinner & Sons {{!}} Fabrics.net Fabrics.net|url=http://info.fabrics.net/the-indian-head-connection-skinner-sons/|access-date=2021-08-03|language=en-US}}</ref>

== In popular culture ==

* Suede's absorbent nature was highlighted in the ''[[Seinfeld]]'' episode "[[The Jacket (Seinfeld)|The Jacket]]", in which [[Jerry Seinfeld (character)|Jerry]] ventures outside into the snow and ruins his exorbitantly priced suede jacket.
* "[[Blue Suede Shoes]]" is a well-known early rock-n-roll song written by [[Carl Perkins]] and also covered by [[Elvis Presley]].
* "[[Weird Al]]" Yankovic wrote and performed the song "[[King of Suede]]".
* "[[Suedehead]]" A skinhead subculture and song by English singer/songwriter "[[Morrissey]]".

== See also ==
*[[Shearing (textiles)]]
*[[Nubuck]]
*[[Voris (designer)|Voris]], 1930s–1940s American fashion designer who worked exclusively in suede
